complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Outline subtasks for creating the multi-workspace skeleton (backend, lambda, mobile, web, infrastructure, docs), wiring each workspace’s package manager, adding shared root tooling (.editorconfig, lint/format configs, Renovate/Dependabot), setting up .github workflows, and documenting Amplify/AWS credential flows given the currently empty repo.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: Repo currently contains only Taskmaster metadata and no product source folders (`rg --files` shows just `CLAUDE.md` plus `.taskmaster/*`), so every workspace, toolchain wrapper, and CI config must be created from scratch while keeping consistent conventions across five stacks, which is a moderately high lift.

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Break down generation of the Spring Boot/WebFlux project, configuration of R2DBC + Flyway profiles, creation of Flyway V1–V5 migrations from the PRD schema, implementation of domain aggregates/repositories, Cognito JWT security/filter wiring, and observability beans/tests.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: There is no existing backend code (`backend/` absent per repo scan), yet the task demands a full reactive Spring stack with database schema, security, and observability described in `.taskmaster/docs/rapid-photo-prd.md:1`, so it requires extensive greenfield implementation plus database/testcontainer setup.

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Detail subtasks covering GeneratePresignedUrl controller/service/policy, UploadJob persistence with concurrency enforcement, ConfirmUpload aggregation + SQS outbox, batch status query projection, and comprehensive reactive/S3/SQS integration tests.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: These slices depend on the yet-to-be-built WebFlux foundation and require coordinating reactive controllers, domain policies, AWS S3/SQS integrations, and command-side projections with load-testing expectations from `.taskmaster/tasks/tasks.json:1`, keeping complexity high.

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Enumerate subtasks for building read-model mappers, implementing the gallery/search/delete/download endpoints with pagination/filtering, adding caching/metrics, and writing repository + WebTestClient tests for auth enforcement.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: Once the command side exists, this task still demands multiple query endpoints, DTO mappers, reactive pagination, signed download links, and caching/metrics layers, all absent in the repo today, yielding significant though slightly lower complexity than the command work.

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Plan subtasks for scaffolding the Lambda package (handler plus image/rekognition/db modules), implementing Pillow-based processing, Rekognition + S3 interactions, PostgreSQL updates with idempotency, structured logging/metrics, and pytest/localstack/load-test coverage.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: No `lambda/` code exists, yet the feature spans image manipulation, AWS services, database updates, idempotent retries, and testing harnesses (per `.taskmaster/docs/rapid-photo-prd.md:1`), making it a complex multi-integration Lambda effort.

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: List subtasks to initialize the Flutter workspace with Amplify config, implement the Riverpod UploadQueueNotifier + persistence, build the Material 3 upload UI components, integrate with backend initiate/confirm APIs + S3 PUTs, and add unit/widget/integration tests.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: With no `mobile/` project present, delivering concurrency-aware upload orchestration, Amplify auth, rich UI, and persistence per task description requires significant new Flutter code and test scaffolding, though bounded to a single client app.

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Define subtasks for creating gallery data services and AsyncNotifiers, building grid/detail/search UI with caching + downloads, handling tag filtering/infinite scroll, integrating Amplify Storage for downloads, and covering unit/widget/integration tests.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: This extends the nonexistent Flutter app with complex UI states (virtualized grids, tag chips, downloads) and backend integrations; dependencies on Task4/6 mean additional coordination but scope remains client-side, yielding similar complexity to Task6.

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Break down initialization of the Vite/React/Tailwind workspace with Amplify auth, construction of the upload queue hook with concurrency/retry logic, development of drag-and-drop/progress UI components, wiring to backend and S3 PUT flows, and authoring unit/component/E2E tests.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: With no `web/` app yet, this task introduces a full React/Amplify stack plus concurrent presigned uploads, progress UI, and rich testing (Vitest + Playwright), representing a sizable but self-contained front-end effort.

complexityAnalysis.taskTitle: React Gallery, Search, and Batch Download
complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Outline subtasks for building paginated/gallery hooks with React Query, implementing virtualized grid/lightbox UI, adding tag search and filters, implementing batch download/zip logic, and covering unit/component/E2E/Perf tests.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: Similar to Task8, this is greenfield React work layering advanced UI behaviors (virtualization, zip downloads) atop APIs that do not yet exist, so it remains a high-effort front-end feature set.

complexityAnalysis.expansionPrompt: Detail subtasks for authoring Terraform modules (networking, data, compute, messaging, CDN), environment compositions, secrets/SSM wiring, GitHub Actions pipelines per workspace, observability stacks (CloudWatch dashboards, alarms, X-Ray), load-test scripts (k6/JMeter) and their CI hooks, plus deployment/runbook documentation.
complexityAnalysis.reasoning: No Terraform or CI/CD assets exist today, yet this task spans provisioning every AWS component, building per-workspace pipelines, observability instrumentation, and automated load-testing aligned with the PRD, making it one of the most complex efforts in the program.
